Trade Truce; Police Officers Killed in the Line of Duty; 9/11 Victim identified; Mattel Cutting Jobs; Bitcoin Making a Comeback2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:42ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Jack Brewer, Paul Wolfowitz, Cory JohnsonNEWSDomestic/NewsInternational072602cb.231Facebook Unfriended on Wall Street This Morning; U.S.-E.U. Trade Truce; Police Officers Killed in the Line of Duty; 9/11 Victim identified; Mattel Cutting Jobs; Bitcoin Making a ComebackMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thanks for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday. It is Thursday, July 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Facebook unfriended on Wall Street this morning. The stock is plunging on disappointing sales and revenue guidance, nearly $150 billion of market value wiped out in the after hours trading session. The stock right now down about 19 percent right now.

Facebook setting the tone for the rest of the tech sector. The biggest names in technology under pressure this morning. Amazon is going to be the one to watch today. It reports after the close. Going into the numbers, the stock is down one and three-quarters percent. Check out Twitter down 3.5 percent, Snap down 4 percent.

Broader markets meanwhile look like this. Dow Industrials are fine, up 30 points. But the Nasdaq taking a hit on the weakness in tech. Nasdaq down 64 points right now, almost 1 percent lower. S&P 500 down a quarter of a percent.

It was a wild session on Wall Street yesterday particularly in the final hour of trading. Stocks surging in just the last 30 minutes of trading on reports of a softening trade dispute between the U.S. and the E.U. President Trump explained why it's important to get a trade deal in place. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The United States and the European Union together count for more than 830 million citizens and more than 50 percent of the global GDP. In other words, together we're more than 50 percent of trade. If we team up, we can make our planet a better, more secure and more prosperous place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Global markets this morning reacting. We've got the CAC 40 in Paris up a third of a percent. The DAX index in Germany up better than 1 percent. The FT 100 in London up just a fraction.

In Europe investors are waiting to hear from the European Central Bank. We will hear from the ECB and get a sense of when interest rates will be on the rise coming up. And we will bring that to you as soon as it hits the tape.

In Asia overnight markets finished mostly lower with the exception of Korea. That was up three-quarters of a percent.

And then this -- censoring conservative ideas; a startling new report says Twitter is shadow banning top Republican officials. It's not happening to Democrats. The outrage coming up this morning.

Bitcoin making a comeback -- the cryptocurrency surging above $8,000 for the first time in months -- a closer look at the crypto craze this morning.

And there's no such thing as a free lunch, right? Well, San Francisco is trying to take away the free food at technology companies' cafeterias. We'll tell you why.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Former NFL star and the Brewer Group CEO Jack Brewer with us this morning; and CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell. Great to see everybody this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Great to be here.

JACK BREWER, CEO, BREWER GROUP: Yes. Great to be here. BARTIROMO: And the big story is Facebook this morning is down now 19 percent, Lindsey -- because people are now questioning about this 30 percent growth number that we've been seeing for so long at Facebook. Looks like that's in the rear view mirror at this point.

BELL: But even declining by high single digits sequentially quarter over quarter, which is the guidance that management provided, you're still getting 20 percent --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: -- top line growth. Where else are you going to get that?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. But you have to wonder if the stock where it's trading at is equal to that kind of growth versus what else we were seeing at Facebook.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I'll point to the Instagram stories issue, because it was in the Instagram stories -- they're not pulling in the same amount of money as ads shown in Facebook and in the Instagram feeds.

And this is particularly troubling because as of next year Facebook had been predicting that the stories would have more essentially traffic than the original photo feeds on Instagram. So again, that's where they were placing their bets. Now they have to figure out a better way to monetize these Facebook stories.

And they have been gaining traction. A lot of people use those rather than just kind of posting the run-of-the-mill photos and videos to their Instagram feeds. They're using those ones that disappear in 24 hours.

BELL: Yes. I think Jack was posting a story earlier this morning.

BARTIROMO: What were you posting?

BREWER: Yes. I post the story -- I always post stories. But they're going to have to evolve that business model on the ad side when you talk about stories. I think at the end of the day you'll see over the next maybe six to 12 months they're going to start using their influencers a little bit more. I think you'll see more partnerships with influencers because those are the ones that are really driving the traffic.

Even -- look at YouTube now. I mean if you go on YouTube now, a lot of those ads and those pieces they're putting out, YouTube is actually assisting the companies in producing those ads.

And so these social media companies are going to have to get more hands-on with the way that they're putting the stories out, with the way that they're actually generating the content.

BARTIROMO: And the news on Facebook is offsetting other positive news in terms of trade. Markets rallied on the results of a meeting yesterday with the European Commission's Mr. Juncker and President Trump.

Joining us right now on the telephone is LJH Investment Advisers managing director Larry Haverty. Larry -- thanks very much for calling in this morning. Your reaction to Facebook?

LARRY HAVERTY, MANAGING DIRECTOR, LJH INVESTMENT ADVISERS: (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Larry -- unfortunately, you're going in and out. We're not hearing you well. Obviously, you're on a cell phone. We would love to get your insights on this.

But of course, $150 billion in lost market value in the after hours trading session is what people are reacting to today. Was it an overreaction in your view?

BELL: No, I mean I think this has been a high flier. It was up 25 percent going into this press (ph). There were high expectations. And you know, we got lucky in the first quarter.

The Cambridge Analytica scandal was not -- you didn't see it in the numbers. Now you're seeing it in the numbers. There are repercussions for this type of activity. And there's --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Especially as they invest more in privacy tools. That's going to cost money.

BELL: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: But it's maybe short-term loss for a long-term gain. These are problems that have to get fixed if Facebook wants to retain this giant user base that it has and continue to grow and monetize. The people are using say WhatsApp and Instagram.

But to shine a spotlight on what the stock is doing, shares hit an all-time high yesterday --

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- and so in less than 24 hours essentially, it's gone into bear market territory with almost down 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: Left it all out.

MCDOWELL: That is so astonishing to see that. And it is -- it's a lesson to people when you invest in a company, a stock that has a really high valuation on it, you better be in for the long haul. You could lose -- if you're going to sell today you could lose 28 percent of whatever you put in yesterday.

BARTIROMO: The "Journal" story was great, going through the tick tock of the conference call and sort of what, you know, Sheryl Sandberg said versus Mark Zuckerberg versus the CFO.

MCDOWELL: Zuckerberg saying Instagram has been this amazing success and highlighting. And then Sheryl Sandberg comes on and --

BARTIROMO: Awesome.

MCDOWELL: -- everything. Yes, "The Lego Movie", "everything is awesome". And then the CFO comes on. Leave it to the money guy to be fair (INAUDIBLE) and go, well, I've got a couple of bombs I'm about to drop on you," 20 minutes into this conference call. . It's not funny. It's not funny.

But there were a lot of problem areas that the finance chief highlighted.

BARTIROMO: And that certainly is setting the tone for technology this morning. Facebook right now down 20 percent.

And then there's this, Trump talking tariffs. President Trump off to Illinois this morning to talk workforce development and tour a steel factory that's reopened as a result of his tariff regulations.

Just in the last hour I spoke with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross who touted the President's tough stance on steel and aluminum tariffs. Here's what he told me this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: So steel and aluminum, there's no intention to abandon those industries. So the President is very happy with the progress they have made in opening new facilities. I'm joining him today as we go out to visit one that had just recently been reopened. He's not going to do anything to destroy steel and aluminum from their new-found substance.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And yet, it's a double edged sword. Both Coca-Cola and General Motors will be raising prices they say on their iconic products in large part because of the fallout over tariffs.

Joining me right now is Ambassador Paul Wolfowitz. He is former deputy secretary of Defense, former ambassador to Indonesia and former assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific Affairs. Ambassador -- good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining me.

PAUL WOLFOWITZ, FORMER AMBASSADOR TO INDONESIA: Nice to be here -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Secretary Ross' notion that the steel and aluminum tariffs are remaining intact. The markets rallied hugely last night on this idea that the E.U. and the U.S. are going to work toward no tariffs but we know that the aluminum and steel tariffs are still in place.

WOLFOWITZ: And I think they're hurting some of our best friends including Japan pretty badly.

BARTIROMO: So your thoughts on this strategy that the President has. You know, he comes into this saying ok, we lost $151 billion with the E.U. We lost you know, $500 billion with China. We want a more level playing field.

And do you think this is all a negotiation, that at the end of the day maybe the U.S. comes out in a better place as it seems like the markets are viewing this?

WOLFOWITZ: Well, I certainly hope so because there's no question, we need a more level playing field. But we could end up with a very, very rocky one instead if this escalates.

BARTIROMO: Because the President and the European Commission president Mr. Juncker yesterday came out very positive and discussed that they are going to have a breakthrough in trade talks to avoid a transatlantic trade war. The two leaders agreeing to hold off on further tariffs signaling a pause in the President's auto tariff threat. Ambassador -- could zero tariffs with Europe become a reality in your view?

WOLFOWITZ: It will certainly surprise me if it happens but it would be a good thing.

BARTIROMO: What is your take in terms of what's happening in terms of a cease fire when it comes to China? President Xi issuing a stark threat to President Trump claiming that there would be no winner in a global trade war.

Your reaction to President Xi's comments? What does yesterday's deal between the U.S. and Europe mean for China?

WOLFOWITZ: I think it puts more pressure on China. And the issue with China is not so much about the tariffs although they're relevant. But the real issue with China is the way it's been stealing intellectual property here, not only by forcing companies to reveal what they have but also by cyber methods, breaking into corporate secrets. I think it's a very, very dangerous trend that they've been on.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLFOWITZ: And I think it's good to be opposing them.

BARTIROMO: So you're glad in terms of the pushback from America to China in terms of the consistent theft of intellectual property?

WOLFOWITZ: If it doesn't get out of control -- but my sense is from Xi's comments is he's much more worried about where it could go than we are.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Ambassador, let me move on to the President's bilateral meeting with Vladimir Putin. National security adviser John Bolton citing special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation for a delay issuing this statement. "The President believes that the next bilateral meeting with President Putin should take place after the Russia witch hunt is over. So we've agreed that it will be after the first of the year."

How do you expect the U.S. policy toward Russia moving forward and any thoughts on the President's foreign policy decisions?

WOLFOWITZ: You know, one of the ironies here is that Putin has obviously succeeded in sowing enormous dissension in the United States over our own political process which is one of his goals. But he's actually ended up with a Russia policy that is probably much tougher than he might have had otherwise and may even get tougher still.

BARTIROMO: So you think that -- then, I guess that's a positive in your view?

WOLFOWITZ: Positive that the meeting's postponed? Absolutely. But what I would like to see more talk about is measures like this Magnitsky Act that put pressure on Russian plutocrats to make it much more difficult for them to hide their money here and to launder it.

And the British (INAUDIBLE) something called the unexplained wealth orders which are now putting a lot of pressure on probably Russians, but maybe other people as well, who are buying expensive property in London through offshore shell companies to hide it. That's a real threat to Putin and his clique.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right. That's why he's apparently going after Bill Browder, who of course, it was Bill Browder's lawyer Mr. Magnitsky who was killed in jail and he was able to get the Magnitsky Act.

Let me ask you about Secretary of State Mike Pompeo yesterday testifying in front of the Senate foreign relations committee facing a barrage of questions aimed at U.S. policy on Russia and on North Korea. Pompeo vowed that the U.S. will not relax sanctions towards Russia but said that we cannot make progress with Moscow unless we're open to discussions. Listen to this clip from yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: President Trump believes the two great nuclear powers should not have a contentious relationship. This is not just in our interest but in the interest of the whole world.

He strongly believes that now is the time for direct communication in our relationship in order to make clear to President Putin that there is the possibility, however remote it might be, to reverse the negative course of our relationship. Otherwise, the administration will continue imposing tough actions against Russia in response to its malign activities.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Ambassador, it looked like Mr. Pompeo did well yesterday. Anything strike you from that testimony?

WOLFOWITZ: Well, I certainly agree with that second part of keeping up the pressure.

I mean it's worth noting, Maria, that when President Reagan was negotiating with the old Soviet Union, he didn't let up the pressure on Poland which was one of their weak spots. And even more impressively when he was working closely with General Secretary Gorbachev to get an arms control agreement that was very important to everybody he made that famous statement about "Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall." So he kept the pressure up in Berlin.

I think the only way you get anywhere with people like Putin is by having pressure on them. If you just try to do it by being nice it never works.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. Ambassador -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

WOLFOWITZ: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Paul Wolfowitz joining us there.

We'll take a break. When we come back, bitcoin is bouncing back. The cryptocurrency jumping above $8,000 for the first time in two months. What's behind the recent gains -- coming up.

Then Twitter's shadow ban -- why some prominent conservatives are now failing to appear in search results on the social media platform. We've got the story and the fallout, coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Breaking news -- two police officers killed in the line of duty.

Cheryl Casone with the details now and headlines -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWOR CORRESPONDENT: We're getting some new details, Maria, on this breaking news. This happened in Milwaukee. A 17- year police veteran was shot and killed by a suspect who was wanted on gun and drug violations. They do have that suspect in custody now. A procession of officers escorted the fallen officer's body to the medical examiner's office. Look at these incredible pictures.

This is the second death of a Milwaukee police officer just this summer. What a show of support.

Meanwhile in Arizona, one officer was shot and killed and the other was injured. This happened last night there. The officers responding to a call about a man driving erratically on the roads.

Well, New York is keeping its promise to 9/11 victims' families 17 years later. Through improved DNA testing the medical examiner's office has identified the 1,642nd victim of that terror attack.

Scott Michael Johnson was 26 years old. He was working for the investment banking firm Keefe, Bruyette and Woods. He was on the 89th floor of the South Tower. The bone belonging to Johnson had been tested dozens of times throughout the years but recent improvements allowed examiners to gain enough DNA evidence to make that match. Johnson -- the first victim to be identified since august of last year.

Well, Mattel is cutting costs and they're cutting jobs. The company slashing 2,200 jobs as they continue to struggle with falling sales after reporting weak and unexpected quarterly results. Mattel, which is of course, well-known for making Barbie and Hot Wheels, also hurt by the closing of Toys R Us which happened recently this year. Shares of Mattel, Maria, are trading lower in the premarket -- ok, a lot lower, down by 11 percent. There you go.

BARTIROMO: Big move there, cutting 2,200 jobs and the stock takes a hit.

CASONE: Which is -- usually it's the opposite we see. That's not good for that company.

BARTIROMO: Thank you -- Cheryl.

Coming up, bitcoin bouncing back this morning, the cryptocurrency jumping above 8,000 for the first time in two months. What's behind that big gain, coming up.

Then, no such thing as a free lunch, right. Why San Francisco is now looking to ban free cafeterias at technology companies -- one of the best perks there is.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Bitcoin optimism is back. The cryptocurrency reaching over $8,000 a token for the first time since May. Ripple chief market strategist Cory Johnson joins us now to talk more about that. Cory -- it's great to see you.

CORY JOHNSON, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, RIPPLE: Good to see you too.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. What do you make of this recent move higher on bitcoin? And tell us how you see the overall market? Because you're really much more bullish on XRP as opposed to bitcoin.

JOHNSON: Yes. Well, I think -- I think for us, you know, Ripple has based some of our software solutions on XRP because we think it's a better technology. We look at XRP as sort of block chain 2.0.

The bitcoin is a fascinating idea but it's really sort of breaking down in terms of its ability to use it, closing transaction is really slow. We're looking at a business problem. And the business problem is moving money across borders.

It is crazy that today I can send a text message to a friend in Rome with emojis and a gif of falling down and clever stuff and I can send an Excel spreadsheet by e-mail to South Africa in 3 seconds. But if I want to move money from New York to Mexico City it takes five days and costs over 500 basis points.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

JOHNSON: That's crazy in this era of technology. So Ripple has created a bunch of software products to really accelerate that process, to move money in less than a minute and for, you know, just basis points. But using XRP as a basis technology for some of the software solutions we can move it so much cheaper and so much more efficiently using XRP. We think that XRP will have great value over time.

BELL: What about consumers? Mastercard just applied for a patent to be able to use cryptocurrencies on credit cards.

JOHNSON: Right.

BELL: Is that the future of currencies?

JOHNSON: I mean we are 100 percent focused on business. I mean I think that there will be lots of better ways for money to move but again, when you talk about moving money, bitcoin's slow. Ether is slow. XRP moves really, really fast just because of the way the technology is a little bit different.

I don't want to give you the technological details but fundamentally money should move as fast as ideas move as fast as data moves. And right now it doesn't. And it's really expensive.

The place that money hurts -- that slow-moving money hurts people is moving money across borders. If you are working and your family is in another country, if you're on vacation in another country, if you're a business and you want to buy products in another country to sell it where you are, it takes so long to move money and costs so much money.

Imagine if your business is selling (ph) with 500 basis points -- the World Bank says it's a 532-basis point cost to move money across borders for anyone. That's a horrible drag on business. We're trying to fix that.

MCDOWELL: What about the regulatory hurdles and head winds country by country in terms of are they rising because again, we talk about no borders in terms of virtual currencies but there are borders and regulators love to make sure that even in the digital world that those borders exist.

JOHNSON: Look, one person's regulation is another person's protection.

MCDOWELL: Right.

JOHNSON: I believe it's really important for investors to be protected. We've seen what happens when there aren't investor protections. We've seen investors lose so much money. And we've seen it in the world of crypto. We've seen some real bad actors involved.

So we're thrilled that regulators are getting involved. It's really interesting. It's not what I expected when I joined this company say six months ago and we're very much engaged in conversations with regulators.

But I'll say that a lot of other countries are moving faster than the U.S. to try to provide really clear lanes of where business can act, what's right and what's wrong.

BARTIROMO: Like China.

JOHNSON: Well, China's a really peculiar case. Most of the bitcoin mining, most of the ether mining is all taking place in places where power is cheap, which is China; and where they've got the access to the best computer chips, which is China. And so China -- most bitcoin is mined in China. Most ether is mined in China.

XRP isn't being mined. It was pre-mined, if you will. So as a result it uses virtually no power when it's, you know, compared to these other things. Running a node in the network is so much cheaper as a result. And there isn't any mining cost with that. So it's a different kind of technology as a result.

But countries like Singapore, countries like Switzerland, countries like Thailand are working really hard to make sure that businesses develop there around block chain. The U.S. is starting to do some things. The SEC has started to try to figure some things out.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOHNSON: But other countries aren't waiting and the entrepreneurs aren't waiting to start business.

BARTIROMO: really exciting opportunity.

Cory -- thanks so much for joining us.

JOHNSON: It's so good to see you.

BARTIROMO: You, too. Great to have you -- Cory Johnson.

MCDOWELL: We've known you a lot of years -- Cory Johnson.

JOHNSON: We're not that old? Come on.

MCDOWELL: No, we're not.

BARTIROMO: And you're still innovating.

JOHNSON: Go figure.

BARTIROMO: Cory Johnson.

Coming up, Twitter's shadow ban -- some prominent conservatives are now failing to appear in search results on the social media platform. We've got the story and the fall out coming next.

And then fighting free lunches -- why two San Francisco lawmakers are trying to do away with free cafeterias at Silicon Valley technology companies. The story coming up.

Back in a minute.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 26th. Your top stories right now, 07:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

Facebook unfriended by investors this morning, take a look at the stock, plummeting better than 20 percent. The company taking a hit after reporting disappointing sales and revenue guidance, the conference call had lots of expectations and they fell short.

It is just the tip of the iceberg for technology. We've got Amazon and Intel reporting this afternoon, those are the two to watch today. Amazon with some high expectations there, going into the quarter down 1-3/4 percent going in to the numbers.

Futures this morning, indicating a mix opening. The Dow Industrials are up 36 points right now but the NASDAQ is down 58 points as technology takes a hit on the Facebook news.

The markets ending the day yesterday higher. Tensions over trade disputes between the U.S. and the E.U. ease as the president spoke with the European Commission President Mr. Juncker and said they are going to work toward an agreement toward zero tariffs. Markets rallied on that. Dow Industrials finished up 172 points. The NASDAQ was up 91.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the indices, money is moving into stocks. The DAX Index up better than one percent. No real agreement on autos and yet the DAX Index in Germany quite strong today, up better than one percent. CAC Quarante up quarter of a percent. The FT-100 unchanged as the European markets await the European Central Bank news this morning.

Asian markets closing mostly in the red overnight. Take a look, the KOSPI was up three quarters of one percent.

President Trump on Twitter declaring a big day for free and fair trade after his meeting with the European Commission president. The president said that the goal would be zero tariffs. I spoke with U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross earlier this morning to get his take.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, SECRETARY, U.S. COMMERCE: Well, you notice on light trucks, there was an exception for automotive products. It said we'd work towards zero tariffs on nonautomotive industrial products. Steel and aluminum, there's no attention to abandon those industries.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Twitter accused of hiding conservative voices in the search results at the company. The company taking heat this morning for so-called "shadow banning." We will tell you all about it with the details coming up.

Then, local businesses are up in arms in San Francisco over free lunches at technology companies. They want to force workers to pay up, leave campus to get food and pay for it. The controversy, coming up.

We're in the middle of the summer blockbuster season where there are big movies, there is IMAX. We are checking in to see surprises the company's got in store for movie goers. We'll check in with the IMAX CEO on earnings and what's ahead.

All that coming up, but first, Facebook shares, falling out of bed this morning, that's for sure. The stock down 20 percent on news from the company's earnings report which basically opened up the idea that growth is slowing down at Facebook as they invest more in security and privacy tools.

Joining us right now on the telephone is Arete senior analyst Richard Kramer. Richard, great to have you this morning. Thanks for joining us. Your reaction to the Facebook news yesterday?

RICHARD KRAMER, SENIOR ANALYST, ARETE (via telephone): Well, I think we had already had a growth slowdown from extremely high levels in our numbers. I don't think that was a big surprise. The biggest surprise was that Facebook is extremely happy to continue spending the kind of money it does, both on cap-ex, on staff growth, on buybacks and so forth.

BARTIROMO: But -- I mean, when you look at the kind of growth numbers that we've been accustomed to at Facebook, 30 percent revenue growth, are those days now in the rear view mirror? Is that the issue here that we're not going to see the kind of growth that we expected in the past?

KRAMER: I think you need to put this in the context of the law of large numbers. And Facebook ended last year at a $40 billion company. And finding an incremental 50 percent growth on top of that, which is the clip that they were running at last year, is -- you know, finding another $20 billion of advertising revenue and that's just simply a very hard to do.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Richard, Lindsey Bell here. Interesting, revenue per user was actually up, which I thought was kind of a highlight, if you could find one. But the real question we've talked about all morning is Instagram, this is supposed to be the growth engine for the company going forward. How are they going to monetize it? They've kind of lagged there. What do you see going forward with that?

KRAMER: I mean, Instagram is incredibly powerful platform. And if you look at brand like, Nike, that has 80 million followers on Instagram, where else will it be able to tap into a global audience to directly market its products to? I wouldn't be overly concerned about that transition. That's something that we've written about earlier this year. I think there's also another important narrative which is Facebook is desperate to avoid regulation, by showing -- saying that they're going to invest more and show lower margins, they're creating a sort of oh, woe is me narrative around the stock that hopefully will keep for them regulators at day.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Richard, it's Dagen McDowell on Instagram, it's not the feeds per say and the ad revenue that that pulls in, it was the ad revenue generated on the Instagram stories because Facebook has predicted that activity on those stories, those photos and videos that disappear after 24 hours, would eclipse the time spent just scrolling through feeds next year. How can they better monetize the ads that are -- and activity in Instagram stories. What do you expect them to do?

KRAMER: Well, I think what you're -- I think what you're pointing out is that story's clearly is a new format and they're transitioning to it and they're willing to take the pain clearly as a company with $42 billion of cash. They can absorb quite a bit of that pain. I think you have to give them some time. Because the next thing that will clearly be coming on Instagram is shoppable icons that -- it will turn into -- rapidly turn into an e-commerce platform alongside stories.

So, there's a lot of directions they can take Instagram. The focus right now is on this transition to stories. But that overlooks a whole range of other options that they have with the platform.

BARTIROMO: Would you buy the stock right here at 173 and change?

KRAMER: Well, we're obviously not supposed to talk about our ratings on the air but we are -- we have a -- we have a positive view on the stock. I don't think that -- I don't think Facebook's days are completely over because they're planning to spend more money. I think if you look out three, five years, and ask yourself will the platforms that they have still be as relevant? It's main Facebook may not be as relevant but Instagram may be a lot more relevant.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Richard, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining the conversation this morning.

KRAMER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Richard Kramer joining us.

Turning now to Twitter being under fire. The social media company facing backlash for reportedly restricting the visibility of top Republicans, but not Democrats, in its search results. The technique is called shadow banning. And according to the Vice News, people like RNC Chair Ronna McDaniel do not appear in Twitter's auto populated dropdown search box on the site.

McDaniel twitted about it yesterday writing this, the notion that social media companies could suppress certain political points of view should concern every American. Twitter owns the public -- owes the public answers to what's really going on.

Joining us right now is Caldwell Strategic Consulting founder and Fox News political analyst Gianno Caldwell. Gianno, good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us. What do you think is going on?

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Good morning. Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on this, Gianno?

CALDWELL: Well, I mean, this comes as no surprise to me and many other conservatives. You think about what happened with Diamond and Silk with (INAUDIBLE) members of congress being impacted by Facebook and other social media networks who don't like the political speech of conservatives, it's fairly problematic. We've seen hearings on this on Capitol Hill. I think that it's now time for members of congress to take a deeper look and begin to put regulations on these companies that do this, that really try to interfere with the equitable actions of every American.

So, whereas as you can be Louis Farrakhan and not be shadow banned or impacted in any way, who obviously uses forms of hate speech or you can be Madonna and threaten the president of the United States in ways. These individuals still have a social media presence that's glowing for their viewers.

So, why is it that conservatives who talk about being pro life, who talk about other capitalism, why is it that they're being shadow banned? This is problematic on many levels and it's something that congress must take a deeper look, a heightened look, I think.

BARTIROMO: You know when we had Kevin McCarthy on and other Republican congressmen, they all said that -- you know, you don't want necessarily the government to come in and start being big government on companies, right? I don't think anybody wants that because we are in a free market. What you would like to see is competition come in and we'll see if this leads to that. Because, obviously, there's an issue here. If Twitter is going to censor conservative ideas.

MCDOWELL: One issue is -- and that's why Facebook is spending so much money on privacy, that's why they're dedicating themselves to improving the protections on the platform. And they've been accused of censor -- obviously, censoring conservative content as well.

But that's -- but they understand the danger of regulation. Or they're beginning to understand that.

But in terms of the problem that you expressed with Ronna McDaniel, it's still apparent, like this is something that Twitter could fix in spontaneously. If you put the name Ronna in the search, Ronna's got a verified Twitter account. But instead, the first results, if you put Ronna in, you get somebody who has a verified account with a few thousand followers, not 85,000 like Ronna McDaniel. You get somebody with a verified account with a few hundred.

And by the way, I follow a lot of conservatives on Twitter and they follow me back but they're not giving me that search result. That's something that Twitter could easily fix and so far they haven't done it.

BARTIROMO: No, they haven't.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: So, Gianno, this is Jack Brewer. What can influencers do, conservative minded influencers, what can we do to really push forward this messaging? Because at the end of the day, these social media companies are dependent upon influencers. That's where people are going, that's who they're following. And so, you know, I'm just trying to figure out, come up with an idea on what steps we can take to make our voices bigger?

CALDWELL: You know, interestingly enough, I think especially when it comes to the shadow banning issue, there's been a lot of folks that have spoken up. That's the reason why we had those big hearings on Capitol Hill. You saw Diamond and Silk actually on Capitol Hill in a hearing where we had this discussion. Many of these social media companies have said that they were taking steps to correct this. But you continue to see the same issue pop up time and time again.

When we have the president of the United States who's a -- the biggest government leader using this service. And we know that there's other government leaders who've been shadow banned as well, members of congress, that's when it's necessities.

In my view, of course, we don't like regulation, competition is great, but this is something that the government is fully using. This is a -- this is a spear where public dialogue is happening on a regular basis. So yes, it's great to have competition but it will take a while before competition is able to compete with that kind of search profile, these social media sites.

BARTIROMO: Right.

CALDWELL: So, yes, this is the time I think that we should be going in and talking about listen, if you're not going to correct this, you made claims time and time again, there should be some form of a penalty because there's voices that are seriously being silenced.

MCDOWELL: Just really quick, Jack Dorsey has been meeting privately a lot of conservative thought leaders and having a lot of discussions. But that talk needs to turn into a walk in terms of the policies and the way that Twitter is actually managed.

BARTIROMO: And it hasn't.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: It has not. Gianno, good to get your insight. Thanks so much.

CALDWELL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon. Gianno Caldwell there.

Coming up, no such thing as a free lunch, right? Well, why San Francisco is now looking to ban free lavish cafeterias at technology companies, one of the best perks for tech workers, that story coming up.

Then, pump up the volume. We are going deeper into the ultimate high quality movie going experience with the CEO of IMAX, coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A move to ban free lunches at technology company cafeterias in an attempt to support local restaurants. Gerri Willis with the details now, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. That's right. If you are one of the thousands of San Francisco workers used to enjoying a free lunch every day at work, get ready for a change. The city's Board of Supervisors wants to ban the free lunch, saying it hurts local restaurants. Look, even the restaurants say they can't compete.

Free lunches are a perk at big tech companies and offered by the likes of Google, Twitter, but also Levi Strauss. That's an old one. There are 51 such employee cafeterias in San Francisco. One supporter of the law banning in house cafeterias said this "We don't want employees biking or driving to their office, staying there all day and going home. This is about getting people out of their office."

However, if the law is passive and only applied a new companies putting a cafeteria is not existing once. Well, the proposals in usual, it's not without president. Nearby Mountain View, California barred Facebook from subsidizing on-site meals for 2,000 workers for the tech company offices. Says one San Francisco restaurant to -- restaurant tour that it's hard to compete with free.

BARTIROMO: So what? I mean, companies are allowed to offer their employees whatever they want. I mean, this is basically to me big government telling companies how to do their business.

WILLIS: Or just mouthy small government, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WILLIS: It's a board of supervisors here.

BARTIROMO: Right, a board of supervisors. Local city supervisors telling technology companies how to pay their employees. That's a perk that companies have a right to give.

BREWER: And what about the food service companies, right? They're most the -- most of them are outsourcing us. So you have you know, major food service companies now that are going to be losing contracts and it makes no sense. Another thing, why don't they just charge them a quarter, come eat a full meal, a quarter.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's good. Then the local restaurants will have to compete with that.

BREWER: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: Why, I can't figure out why some of these companies haven't moved to more free market cities? I know that all the talent is in Silicon Valley and in San Francisco.

WILLIS: Well, they have moved south, right?

MCDOWELL: And some of them have moved to Texas which is a no income tax state, maybe even -- I know, I think Zappos is based in Las Vegas, of all places. But that's owned by Amazon.

But I'll point out, again, it's because these bureaucrats think they know better --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- than people who have created some of the greatest companies in the history of America.

BARTIROMO: That's why they're getting the (INAUDIBLE) that they're getting. Because they got all these perks. So what? They're allowed.

WILLIS: What if you're an employee of one of these companies and city hall saying we're going to take this away from you. I would really be pissed. Is this really going to help them? I don't think so. This is exactly like the big debate three years ago over busses, Google busses. Local groups complained hey, this is texploitation. They're there ganking up major arteries in the city.

By the way, it was free to the city to transport Google employees. They didn't have to pay for city busses --

BARTIROMO: You're right.

WILLIS: -- to get people anywhere.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible. I think we all agree.

MCDOWELL: Listen, I lived in San Francisco --

BELL: Keep out of the business.

MCDOWELL: -- for less than a year and I hated it for that very reason.

WILLIS: We were there at the same time.

MCDOWELL: Yes, we we're there at the same --

BARTIROMO: City officials -- City officials trying to tell businesses how to run their businesses. Gerri, thank you.

WILLIS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Speaking of technology, President Trump is just tweeting this, he says this, Twitter shadow banning prominent Republicans, not good. We will look into this discriminatory and illegal practice at once. Many complaints.

Yes, we were just talking about this, obviously. We're going to take a short break. When we come back, blockbusters on the big, big screen.

I'm talking to the CEO of IMAX next hour about his company's high quality theater experience and summer movie going surprises. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Wow. What a clip, that was a clip from "Mission: Impossible- Fallout". The sixth installment of the wildly successful franchise of "Mission Impossible". The Tom Cruise led blockbuster is the latest IMAX offering. It hit screens nationwide tomorrow -- tonight.

IMAX meanwhile, reporting second quarter earnings last night in earnings per share $00.30 on 98.3 million revenue. EPS beating expectations with revenue narrowly missing expectations.

Joining us right now is the CEO of IMAX, Richard Gelfond. Richard, it's great to see you.

RICHARD GELFOND, CEO, IMAX: Great to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

GELFOND: I'm happy to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good quarter.

GELFOND: Very good quarter.

BARTIROMO: What drove the quarter?

GELFOND: Well, first of all, the second quarter was the highest box office quarter in the history of the movie business.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

GELFOND: Somewhat surprising, people think it's somewhat stagnant industry but it's actually still growing. And IMAX's case, what we do is global blockbusters. So, a large majority of our revenues were international. We did over $100 million in China in box office, over $100 million domestically and over $100 million in the rest of the world. We were firing on all cylinders. I think the public has an appetite for these blockbusters in a premium way and that's where IMAX's fits.

BARTIROMO: That's really important information that you're giving us. Because the international story is such an important growth story for so many companies, IMAX included. You haven't been caught up in this tariff fight with China.

GELFOND: No, we haven't. You know, I don't think we will either. And some of the reasons for that, Maria, are it's been a very good relationship between Hollywood and China. So Hollywood's made a lot of money exporting its films to China. We have a separate public company in China that's worth over $1 billion, a big business. We do a big part of the Chinese box office. And for the Chinese, they're portrayed in a different way than they were years ago.

So, they're not the bad guys anymore and they're not -- you know, the communist enemies. They're portrayed, you look at movies like "The Martian" or you look at movies like "The Great Wall", in a very favorable way. So, I don't think China wants to poke an eye at Hollywood right now. I don't think that works.

BARTIROMO: Did you have to give up any of your technology, did you have to give up any of the secrets of IMAX in order to get your company -- you know, in a foothold in China?

GELFOND: We didn't. And we didn't -- initially, we didn't grow with Chinese partners. We did it ourselves. On the other hand though, we had an ugly episode about seven or eight years ago where someone, a former employee stole some of our technology and they were backed by the Chinese government. And it was drawn out.

So, you know, I think the government has something there when they talk about protecting the theft of I.P. And I think China's a real world power now. They're not a disrupter. They're the status quo. They have more engineers than anyone graduating in the world. And I think they have to be part of the world community and protect I.P.

BARTIROMO: The best part of IMAX is the experience. That's why you're seeing the growth you are in Saudi Arabia. In China you're looking at building and expanding, throughout the Middle East.

Tell us what's on top in terms of the big movies and also what you're expecting in terms of the Middle East and where the growth comes from next.

GELFOND: Well, Saudi Arabia is a promising market. It just opened up to cinema a few months ago. And we are the second theater -- commercial theater ever in Saudi Arabia with Vox, AMC opened the first commercial theater there. India's a very big growth market for us now. We have -- I think, 35 theaters in the Middle East today. They love the Western movies.

BARTIROMO: Wow, fantastic.

GELFOND: "Black Panther" played amazing in the Middle East.

BARTIROMO: That did very well. And I know you have "Aqua Man" coming up, you've got the Fantastics.

GELFOND: "Fantastic Beasts".

BARTIROMO: The "Fantastic Beasts".

BARTIROMO: "Ant-Man".

BARTIROMO: Richard, you're going to be our special guest this weekend in Wall Street. We'll see you soon. Thank you so much. Richard --

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 26th.

Trade Truce; Police Officers Killed in the Line of Duty; 9/11 Victim identified; Mattel Cutting Jobs; Bitcoin Making a ComebackLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thanks for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday. It is Thursday, July 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Facebook unfriended on Wall Street this morning. The stock is plunging on disappointing sales and revenue guidance, nearly $150 billion of market value wiped out in the after hours trading session. The stock right now down about 19 percent right now.

Facebook setting the tone for the rest of the tech sector. The biggest names in technology under pressure this morning. Amazon is going to be the one to watch today. It reports after the close. Going into the numbers, the stock is down one and three-quarters percent. Check out Twitter down 3.5 percent, Snap down 4 percent.

Broader markets meanwhile look like this. Dow Industrials are fine, up 30 points. But the Nasdaq taking a hit on the weakness in tech. Nasdaq down 64 points right now, almost 1 percent lower. S&P 500 down a quarter of a percent.

It was a wild session on Wall Street yesterday particularly in the final hour of trading. Stocks surging in just the last 30 minutes of trading on reports of a softening trade dispute between the U.S. and the E.U. President Trump explained why it's important to get a trade deal in place. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The United States and the European Union together count for more than 830 million citizens and more than 50 percent of the global GDP. In other words, together we're more than 50 percent of trade. If we team up, we can make our planet a better, more secure and more prosperous place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Global markets this morning reacting. We've got the CAC 40 in Paris up a third of a percent. The DAX index in Germany up better than 1 percent. The FT 100 in London up just a fraction.

In Europe investors are waiting to hear from the European Central Bank. We will hear from the ECB and get a sense of when interest rates will be on the rise coming up. And we will bring that to you as soon as it hits the tape.

In Asia overnight markets finished mostly lower with the exception of Korea. That was up three-quarters of a percent.

And then this -- censoring conservative ideas; a startling new report says Twitter is shadow banning top Republican officials. It's not happening to Democrats. The outrage coming up this morning.

Bitcoin making a comeback -- the cryptocurrency surging above $8,000 for the first time in months -- a closer look at the crypto craze this morning.

And there's no such thing as a free lunch, right? Well, San Francisco is trying to take away the free food at technology companies' cafeterias. We'll tell you why.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Former NFL star and the Brewer Group CEO Jack Brewer with us this morning; and CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell. Great to see everybody this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Great to be here.

JACK BREWER, CEO, BREWER GROUP: Yes. Great to be here. BARTIROMO: And the big story is Facebook this morning is down now 19 percent, Lindsey -- because people are now questioning about this 30 percent growth number that we've been seeing for so long at Facebook. Looks like that's in the rear view mirror at this point.

BELL: But even declining by high single digits sequentially quarter over quarter, which is the guidance that management provided, you're still getting 20 percent --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: -- top line growth. Where else are you going to get that?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. But you have to wonder if the stock where it's trading at is equal to that kind of growth versus what else we were seeing at Facebook.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I'll point to the Instagram stories issue, because it was in the Instagram stories -- they're not pulling in the same amount of money as ads shown in Facebook and in the Instagram feeds.

And this is particularly troubling because as of next year Facebook had been predicting that the stories would have more essentially traffic than the original photo feeds on Instagram. So again, that's where they were placing their bets. Now they have to figure out a better way to monetize these Facebook stories.

And they have been gaining traction. A lot of people use those rather than just kind of posting the run-of-the-mill photos and videos to their Instagram feeds. They're using those ones that disappear in 24 hours.

BELL: Yes. I think Jack was posting a story earlier this morning.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A move to ban free lunches at technology company cafeterias in an attempt to support local restaurants. Gerri Willis with the details now, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. That's right. If you are one of the thousands of San Francisco workers used to enjoying a free lunch every day at work, get ready for a change. The city's Board of Supervisors wants to ban the free lunch, saying it hurts local restaurants. Look, even the restaurants say they can't compete.

Free lunches are a perk at big tech companies and offered by the likes of Google, Twitter, but also Levi Strauss. That's an old one. There are 51 such employee cafeterias in San Francisco. One supporter of the law banning in house cafeterias said this "We don't want employees biking or driving to their office, staying there all day and going home. This is about getting people out of their office."

However, if the law is passive and only applied a new companies putting a cafeteria is not existing once. Well, the proposals in usual, it's not without president. Nearby Mountain View, California barred Facebook from subsidizing on-site meals for 2,000 workers for the tech company offices. Says one San Francisco restaurant to -- restaurant tour that it's hard to compete with free.

BARTIROMO: So what? I mean, companies are allowed to offer their employees whatever they want. I mean, this is basically to me big government telling companies how to do their business.

WILLIS: Or just mouthy small government, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WILLIS: It's a board of supervisors here.

BARTIROMO: Right, a board of supervisors. Local city supervisors telling technology companies how to pay their employees. That's a perk that companies have a right to give.

BREWER: And what about the food service companies, right? They're most the -- most of them are outsourcing us. So you have you know, major food service companies now that are going to be losing contracts and it makes no sense. Another thing, why don't they just charge them a quarter, come eat a full meal, a quarter.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's good. Then the local restaurants will have to compete with that.

BREWER: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: Why, I can't figure out why some of these companies haven't moved to more free market cities? I know that all the talent is in Silicon Valley and in San Francisco.

WILLIS: Well, they have moved south, right?

MCDOWELL: And some of them have moved to Texas which is a no income tax state, maybe even -- I know, I think Zappos is based in Las Vegas, of all places. But that's owned by Amazon.

But I'll point out, again, it's because these bureaucrats think they know better --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- than people who have created some of the greatest companies in the history of America.

BARTIROMO: That's why they're getting the (INAUDIBLE) that they're getting. Because they got all these perks. So what? They're allowed.

WILLIS: What if you're an employee of one of these companies and city hall saying we're going to take this away from you. I would really be pissed. Is this really going to help them? I don't think so. This is exactly like the big debate three years ago over busses, Google busses. Local groups complained hey, this is texploitation. They're there ganking up major arteries in the city.

By the way, it was free to the city to transport Google employees. They didn't have to pay for city busses --

BARTIROMO: You're right.

WILLIS: -- to get people anywhere.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible. I think we all agree.

MCDOWELL: Listen, I lived in San Francisco --

BELL: Keep out of the business.

MCDOWELL: -- for less than a year and I hated it for that very reason.

WILLIS: We were there at the same time.

MCDOWELL: Yes, we we're there at the same --

BARTIROMO: City officials -- City officials trying to tell businesses how to run their businesses. Gerri, thank you.

WILLIS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Speaking of technology, President Trump is just tweeting this, he says this, Twitter shadow banning prominent Republicans, not good. We will look into this discriminatory and illegal practice at once. Many complaints.

Yes, we were just talking about this, obviously. We're going to take a short break. When we come back, blockbusters on the big, big screen.

I'm talking to the CEO of IMAX next hour about his company's high quality theater experience and summer movie going surprises. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Wow. What a clip, that was a clip from "Mission: Impossible- Fallout". The sixth installment of the wildly successful franchise of "Mission Impossible". The Tom Cruise led blockbuster is the latest IMAX offering. It hit screens nationwide tomorrow -- tonight.

IMAX meanwhile, reporting second quarter earnings last night in earnings per share $00.30 on 98.3 million revenue. EPS beating expectations with revenue narrowly missing expectations.

Joining us right now is the CEO of IMAX, Richard Gelfond. Richard, it's great to see you.

RICHARD GELFOND, CEO, IMAX: Great to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

GELFOND: I'm happy to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good quarter.

GELFOND: Very good quarter.

BARTIROMO: What drove the quarter?

GELFOND: Well, first of all, the second quarter was the highest box office quarter in the history of the movie business.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

GELFOND: Somewhat surprising, people think it's somewhat stagnant industry but it's actually still growing. And IMAX's case, what we do is global blockbusters. So, a large majority of our revenues were international. We did over $100 million in China in box office, over $100 million domestically and over $100 million in the rest of the world. We were firing on all cylinders. I think the public has an appetite for these blockbusters in a premium way and that's where IMAX's fits.

BARTIROMO: That's really important information that you're giving us. Because the international story is such an important growth story for so many companies, IMAX included. You haven't been caught up in this tariff fight with China.

GELFOND: No, we haven't. You know, I don't think we will either. And some of the reasons for that, Maria, are it's been a very good relationship between Hollywood and China. So Hollywood's made a lot of money exporting its films to China. We have a separate public company in China that's worth over $1 billion, a big business. We do a big part of the Chinese box office. And for the Chinese, they're portrayed in a different way than they were years ago.

So, they're not the bad guys anymore and they're not -- you know, the communist enemies. They're portrayed, you look at movies like "The Martian" or you look at movies like "The Great Wall", in a very favorable way. So, I don't think China wants to poke an eye at Hollywood right now. I don't think that works.

BARTIROMO: Did you have to give up any of your technology, did you have to give up any of the secrets of IMAX in order to get your company -- you know, in a foothold in China?

GELFOND: We didn't. And we didn't -- initially, we didn't grow with Chinese partners. We did it ourselves. On the other hand though, we had an ugly episode about seven or eight years ago where someone, a former employee stole some of our technology and they were backed by the Chinese government. And it was drawn out.

So, you know, I think the government has something there when they talk about protecting the theft of I.P. And I think China's a real world power now. They're not a disrupter. They're the status quo. They have more engineers than anyone graduating in the world. And I think they have to be part of the world community and protect I.P.

BARTIROMO: The best part of IMAX is the experience. That's why you're seeing the growth you are in Saudi Arabia. In China you're looking at building and expanding, throughout the Middle East.

Tell us what's on top in terms of the big movies and also what you're expecting in terms of the Middle East and where the growth comes from next.

GELFOND: Well, Saudi Arabia is a promising market. It just opened up to cinema a few months ago. And we are the second theater -- commercial theater ever in Saudi Arabia with Vox, AMC opened the first commercial theater there. India's a very big growth market for us now. We have -- I think, 35 theaters in the Middle East today. They love the Western movies.

BARTIROMO: Wow, fantastic.

GELFOND: "Black Panther" played amazing in the Middle East.

BARTIROMO: That did very well. And I know you have "Aqua Man" coming up, you've got the Fantastics.

GELFOND: "Fantastic Beasts".

BARTIROMO: The "Fantastic Beasts".

BARTIROMO: "Ant-Man".

BARTIROMO: Richard, you're going to be our special guest this weekend in Wall Street. We'll see you soon. Thank you so much. Richard --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 26th. END

urn:contentItem:5PKK-CNS1-F0J6-J25P-00000-00FACEBOOK UNFRIENDED;Technology2017-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:42ZLexisNexisPERSPECTIVEPg. 19FACEBOOK UNFRIENDEDTechnologyJohn Kehoe

Silicon Valley stockmarket darlings are in the crosshairs of government regulators in the United States, Europe, China and Australia, writes John Kehoe.

Facebook is losing friends in Washington and big online technology platforms are under seige. The social media network, data and advertising company's share price this week suffered its biggest one day fall of the year. Investors were spooked by a disturbing Washington Post report about Facebook's role peddling Russian-funded, highly targeted misinformation to hurt Hillary Clinton in the election and to inflame racial and social divisions across America.

Silicon Valley stock market darlings are in the crosshairs of government regulators in the US, Europe, China and Australia.

Big tech's dissemination of fake news, potential invasion of privacy, oligopoly power, facilitation of terrorism plots and spreading of extremist propaganda are top of mind for politicians gunning for tech titans. Like the powerful Microsoft in the 1990s, the biggest immediate threat to the tech giants may not be from competitors, but heavy-handed regulation.

The debate is shifting from a traditional economic question about monopoly market power to growing concerns about the social clout and responsibility of tech platforms controlled by the likes of Facebook, Google and Amazon.

Their sophisticated algorithms perusing people's personal data from social media posts, clicks, internet searches and online purchases are influencing what news and advertisements we see.

"That obviously impacts how people view the world," says University of South Florida communications associate professor Kelli Burns. "People don't understand the extent to which their data are being interconnected."

Calls around the world are growing for the Silicon Valley giants to be more strictly policed like traditional media companies, regulated similar to public utilities or perhaps even broken up.

Russian-related entities allegedly spent more than $100,000 on Facebook ads to manipulate American voter sentiment, including by targeting ads to fire up black rights group supporters and their opponents in a racially charged election campaign.

Facebook has caved in to pressure by agreeing to hand over to Congress more than 3000 politically themed advertisements paid for by these Russian operatives during the presidential election campaign.

Facebook, Google and Twitter executives have been called to testify to the US Senate Intelligence Committee probing how tech platforms assisted foreign interference in the election. Twitter executives on Thursday appeared behind closed doors before committee staff. Vice-chairman, Democrat Mark Warner, said their testimony was "deeply disappointing" and "inadequate on almost every level".

Twitter "showed an enormous lack of understanding ... about how serious this issue is, the threat it poses to democratic institutions," Warner said.

Twitter disclosed in a blog post that it had uncovered 201 suspicious accounts linked to dodgy Russian operatives, shutting down 22 corresponding to 450 fake accounts that Facebook admitted to investigators.

In an odd twist, President Donald Trump meanwhile lashed out on Twitter against Facebook this week, claiming it was "always anti-Trump", a reference to long-standing perceptions from conservatives that the network's algorithms give more prominence to left-wing opinions. Yet the left alleges that Russia's misinformation disseminated on Facebook helped tip the US election away from Democrat Hillary Clinton.

A besieged Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg felt compelled to respond to Trump this week. In an about-face from his post-election insistence that it was a "crazy idea" that fake news on Facebook influenced the election, the tech billionaire admitted he had been "dismissive and I regret it. We will do our part to defend against nation states attempting to spread misinformation and subvert elections."

Australian intelligence agencies are watching the proceedings, aware the local system is not immune to influence peddling from China and other foreign actors.

"We have similar vulnerabilities and it's led to an active debate in Australia," Australia's former top intelligence and defence chief Dennis Richardson said.

"We'll be really interested in the outcome of the special counsel's investigations, mainly from the point of view of what degree of influence did the Russians seek to engage during your election."

Traditional media such as newspapers and television are relinquishing power and revenue to these disruptive tech giants.

Facebook and Google annually earn more than $US100 billion in advertising revenue.

Facebook has tried to avoid being labelled or regulated as a news media company, but experts such as President Barack Obama's former cyber-security adviser Ben Flatgard say it undoubtedly is.

"Facebook is not just an online software company, they're a news company as well," Flatgard says in an interview with AFR Weekend.

Some 62 per cent of American adults access news on social media, according to think tank the Pew Research Centre.

Google controls almost 90 per cent of the internet search market in Australia and Europe, giving it enormous insight into people's preferences, habits and behaviour.

The potential of artificial intelligence, in-home and in-vehicle devices and systems such as Apple's intelligent personal assistant, Siri, and Amazon's voice controlled system, Alexa, will unearth new opportunities for big tech to know what we are doing, talking about and how we are thinking.

US senators have introduced a bipartisan bill to improve cyber security of the "internet-of-things" that is estimated to include 20 billion devices by 2020.

America's five largest tech companies are now valued at a $US3 trillion.

Despite Facebook's 4.5 per cent share price plunge on Monday, it is still up more than 40 per cent, thanks to this year's huge tech industry stock rally.

Consumers are so far not revolting with their clicks. Facebook has a stunning two billion monthly active users, up 17 per cent on a year ago. Yet, as they say, with great power comes great responsibility. So the drumbeat grows louder for various government interventions, such as the Turnbull government's push to force Apple and other tech firms to help unlock encryption on devices of criminal suspects.

Google Australia and New Zealand managing director Jason Pellegrino said this week the Silicon Valley giant had improved YouTube after advertisers boycotted the video-sharing platform because their brands were appearing alongside extremist and undesirable content.

In the case of weeding out disinformation online, former Obama cyber security adviser Flatgard, who will arrive in Australia next week for a three-month secondment at the US Studies Centre at the University of Sydney, says self-regulation by the industry is the best first step.

The industry is nimbler and more knowledgeable than government and can create consistency across international borders.

"Tech platforms and social media companies could look to put together a cooperative organisation that would look to tackle the problem of disinformation and foreign influence operations," Flatgard says.

"This sort of organisation could establish principles that member companies voluntarily adhere to, as well as standards of practice for dealing with the problem."

Google's Project Owl initiative aims to promote more authoritative content and eliminate fake news from its search results.

Over-regulation by governments might verge on censorship and impinge on freedom of speech.

That said, big tech is not perfect in this area either. A scholarly critic at an influential Google-funded think tank, The New America Foundation, was sacked last month after praising the European Union's record (EURO)2.42 billion ($3.63 billion) fine against the search giant for breaching EU antitrust rules and abusing dominance.

Still, there is an open question about whether big tech's dominance will last.

Eric Goldman, a Silicon Valley lawyer turned director of the High Tech Law Institute at Santa Clara University, doubts Facebook and Google's dominance will be sustained over the long term. "The media environment is continually shifting and reconfiguring at a very record clip," he says.

He points to similar concerns 40 years ago that a small number of US national newspapers and television networks controlled the news flow. Now pay television is being disrupted by cheaper online streaming like Netflix and the newspaper industry has been upended by big tech.

Myspace was obliterated by Facebook. Yahoo! dominated the internet search market in the 1990s before Google took over. America Online, the software services company that allowed computer users to access the internet community, suffered a similar fate when broadband destroyed the dial-up internet access model.

"We have been here before and we can learn some lessons," Goldman says.

"I think the drumbeat about the power Google and Facebook have is helpful to remind companies that their decisions have potentially outsized consequences." P

urn:contentItem:5Y45-R4G1-DY2R-202C-00000-00Facebook unveils details of its content-oversight board;Online governance2020-02-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:43ZLexisNexisBUSINESSFacebook unveils details of its content-oversight boardOnline governanceMENLO PARK

Facebook prepares to hand decisions about contentious content to an independent arbiter

IN NOVEMBER 1999 the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN), which oversees the web's address book, held its inaugural annual gathering. Two decades later the online world faces another constitutional moment, this time courtesy of a company which has profited from the internet's stupendous growth—and is blamed for many of its ills, from privacy abuses to the spread of disinformation. On January 28th Facebook unveiled a draft of the bylaws of what it calls an "oversight board": an independent group of experts charged with the power to review—and overturn—decisions by the firm's army of content moderators. The world's largest social-media conglomerate hopes to have the body up and running in a few months.

Some hope the entity will evolve into an online ombudsman—perhaps even a "supreme court" for other big Western internet platforms—to oversee not just content moderation, but data-gathering and algorithm design. Others view it as no more than Facebook's figleaf: an attempt to forestall real regulation and palm off responsibility for controversial posts. What should users, regulators and investors make of it?

The board certainly looks like a serious effort at institution-building—something "no firm has ever done before", in the words of Kate Klonick of St John's University School of Law in New York, who was allowed to play fly on the wall as the board's contours were drawn up. Facebook hired a (majority-female) team of 12 people, mostly lawyers, to oversee the body's creation. Some used to work at the White House and the UN; others came from media firms and consultancies. Over the past year they solicited input from more than 2,500 people at 60-odd workshops around the world.

The result is unique: a sort of regulatory startup. The board will have its own staff of 30-40, budget (Facebook has earmarked $130m over six years) and a trust to manage it all. Facebook will appoint the first three co-chairs, who will then recruit other members (for a total of 40, each serving a twice-renewable three-year term). The board will have its own website to receive and review appeals. These can be lodged by users of Facebook (and of Instagram, its photo-sharing app) who feel their post has been unfairly removed and not restored. If the company itself is having trouble deciding whether to restore content, it too can file "emergency requests".

Each submission triggers a 90-day process. The emergency requests will be handled faster: in 30 days. If the board agrees to hear a case, a group of five members (who will remain anonymous for security reasons) consults experts and makes a decision, which it must present in plain language. Facebook has a week to comply with a ruling (and can apply it to selfsame content elsewhere on the network). The board can also make "policy recommendations", such as amending Facebook's "community standards". Though these are non-binding, the firm will have to explain itself publicly if it chooses to ignore them.

Internet-governance nerds have questions aplenty. Will users and authorities deem the board legitimate? Much will hinge on the geographic and biographical diversity of its initial members, reckons Ms Klonick. Will it have the capacity to deal with appeals? The board is expected to consider no more than a few dozen cases a year, compared with 3.4m posts Facebook declined to restore in the first quarter of 2019 alone (not counting spam, see chart). Some fear that Facebook could flood it with emergency requests to distract from inconvenient ones for the company.

Most important of all, how powerful and independent will Facebook allow the board to become? And how will it affect the firm's business? The answer is not very and not much—for now. The board's decisions will be based not on real-world laws but on the community standards, which are vague. Initially it will only rule whether individual pictures and posts ought to have been taken down, though the company promises to extend the board's ambit to entire Facebook pages and groups and also to whether certain posts should be up in the first place, once the technical infrastructure is in place. If this makes the social network seem more salubrious, it may lure more corporate advertisers, the fount of Facebook's revenues (which grew more slowly last quarter than ever before).

Things would get more complicated were the board granted a say on how Facebook gathers data or designs algorithms. The company does not rule out the possibility. But Nathaniel Persily of Stanford Law School argues that broadening the board's remit too far, too fast, could be tough. Unlike for content, he observes, no proven judicial model exists for reviewing algorithms. More cynically, Dipayan Ghosh of Harvard University, who once worked at Facebook, doubts the firm would ever accept limits on the data it collects or what content its algorithms show in the Facebook newsfeed.

The last set of unknowns concerns how others, notably governments and rival platforms, will react. If Big Tech takes up Facebook's invitation to sign up to its creation, it could indeed turn into a court of appeal for cyberspace. This looks unlikely in the near term: why would a Google let someone else tie its hands? Some governments, for their part, may see the board as competing with official efforts to regulate speech online. However, both could yet find the nascent entity useful: a complement to government action and, if pressure on internet firms to moderate content mounts, a substitute for bodies they would otherwise need to convene themselves.

A lot rests on how the oversight board turns out in practice. This will take time to assess. Even 20 years after its birth ICANN is a work in progress; just look at the controversy over the recent $1bn sale of .org, a domain mostly used by charities, to a private-equity firm. At a time when the internet is torn between its non-commercial roots and its hyper-commercial present, Facebook's experiment is worth pursuing.

Facebook's self-examination
